At the same time, it is consistent with the results obtained in the ANSYS simulation, which assumes that there is a greater deterioration due to the possibility of spore accumulation in those segments.Compelling the colour paletteTo identify the internal nature of the degradation observed in Serra’s artwork, we devised an exploratory minimally invasive sampling of the northern region of interest. From the experimental data in Fig. 5A and Table 6, it is quite revealing to assess the artist’s colour palette habituated during this period of time to fabricate the apparent green colour 45. Figure 6A exhibits one of the regions of interest chosen to collect millimetric samples (roughly 0.5 \(\hbox {mm}^{2}\)) with a scalpel from slightly damaged locations. As can also be seen from Fig. 6B46, we carried out an identification of the fluorescent pigment47 with madder lake from the Pigment Checker from Cultural Heritage Science Open Source (CHSOS)12. In order to observe the stratigraphies of individual samples using optical microscopy, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and energy dispersive X ray spectroscopy (EDX), we embedded cross sections in epoxy resin which corroborate the following findings: (1) the structure corresponds to typically 2 to 4 layers, (2) based on crystals morphology and apparent colour, the elemental composition and historical knowledge, we inferred the associate pigment used by the artist, (3) the materials for the ground coincide with barium sulphate (\(\hbox {BaSO}_{4}\)) of natural origin i.e. barite, lead white (\(\hbox {Pb(OH)}_{2} \cdot\)2PbCO) and small traces of calcium carbonate (\(\hbox {CaCO}_{3}\)), (4) the secondary green colour was assembled using natural ultramarine (\(\hbox {Na}_{7}\hbox {Al}_{6}\hbox {Si}_{6}\hbox {O}_{24}\hbox {S}_{3}\)) and yellow ocher (\(\alpha\)-FeOOH) pigments. The elemental composition of the region of interest of the cross-section was identified by SEM-EDX48, see Fig. 6A.5, in order to determine the average size of each pigment and conduct the first ever study on Serra’s palette. Table 5 presents an overview of the particle size along with the complex morphology of each material used which allow us, based on evidence, to suggest that the ultramarine pigment and barite is from a natural origin. We hypothesize that the ground contains mainly barite, lead white pigment all mixed with traces of calcium carbonate. It is important to bear in mind that these suggested materials were widely used at the time by contemporary artists such as Van Gogh49,50.Fig. 6Serra’s colour palette: from a macroscopic painting to pigment crystals. The last column includes the main elements for every type of pigment.Full size tableConclusionsThese research aimed to examine for the first time Serra’s paintings under non-controlled environmental conditions in a historic heritage building. It methodically assesses the deterioration, biodeterioration, and chromatic alteration, along with the artist’s color palette. One of the most significant outcomes of this cutting-edge multidisciplinary research, assembled by our fluid simulation using solid particle dynamics in the environment chamber along with experimental data of wind speed, temperature, and particle size, among others, was the recognition of specific zones, at the artworks, which could be affected by their visual appearance over the time since the painting’s creation. The second major finding to emerge was that following the regions of interest previously obtained, we identified a considerable amount of deterioration patterns, biodeterioration microorganisms, and degradation of colour in the paintings. This finding has important suggestions for establishing affordable, compact, efficient, accessible, and novel non-destructive techniques, especially in the extreme climate and humidity of the tropics in Latin America in historic heritage buildings. The third significant finding of this investigation was that in an exploratory experiment we recognized the main artist’s colour palette, which includes: madder lake, lead white, calcium carbonate, yellow ocher, natural ultramarine, and natural barite. There is abundant room for further progress in determining the stratigraphic’s internal nature of the degradation of colour discovered in the outer green layers of the painting.MethodsPiece of study and characteristicsThe artwork of the ceiling (Danthe and Raphael) in the MO of the NTCR is made with the marouflage technique, which consists of adhering manufactured artworks on a flexible support to a more rigid support. Due to its large dimensions, the support was made with tongue and groove joint wood. On the other hand, the mural was made on a brick support covered with stucco, the same material used in the construction of the NTCR building6,14.According to the information given by the administration of the NTCR and the observation, during approximately 1998 there was a restoration of the artworks in this room. Specifically for the murals they did a reintegration of the colour and improved the support of the mural. In the case of the ceiling, there is no documental, experienced, or physical evidence of a restoration. The administration has established some preventive conservation, which includes restricted public access inside the room and natural ventilation during some days of the week51.Multispectral imagingWe generated visible (VIS) and ultraviolet (UV) photographs based on the procedure described by our previous investigations12,13. Briefly, photographs were acquired using a Nikon D5300 camera with an AF-S DX Micro-NIKKOR 40mm f/2.8G lens, and was adjusted in order to obtain high resolution photos (24 megapixels). A white balance was carried out for all the photographs 52 and a pigment reference named Cultural Heritage Open Source Pigments Checker (CHSOS) pigment reference was used.Aerial fungal contamination of the NTCRThe fungal contamination of seven rooms of the NTCR was determined by measuring the concentration of aerial fungal spores via an active sampling. The former names of the sampled areas were Hall next to the Ladies’ Cafeteria, Men”s Canteen, Hall next to the Men’s Canteen, NTCR Management Office, Smoking Lounge for Ladies, Smoking Lounge for Men, and the Presidential Teather Box (see Supplementary Figure S1). These locations were selected because large format paintings are found there . A Burkard Personal Volumetric Air Sampler (Burkard Manufacturing Co. Ltd., United Kingdom) was used to collect the airborne spore particles53. The samples were collected on the last Friday of every month, for a year, starting in January 2022 (except in June and December because the NTCR was closed on said dates due to a hurricane and holidays, respectively). The instrument operates at a nominal air throughput of 10 liters per minute and deposits them onto a glass slide covered by a thin layer of Vaseline or petroleum gel. The spores obtained through the layer of Vaseline, were counted and identified using a light microscope Olympus CX31 (Olympus Life Science, Waltham, MA, USA) at 400 X. Identification of species and groups of interest was done using the atlas “Aeroallergen Identification” (American College of Allergy and Immunology, University of Michigan, November 10th, 1999). The significant differences between the spore concentration by month were determined using a one-way ANOVA test with a Post Hoc Tukey. Statistical significance was defined using a p value less than 0.05. The statistical analysis was made with the software SPSS version 20 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, Ill, USA).Aerial contamination of the MODue to the high fungal spore concentration found in the MO during the yearly survey, further studies were conducted: passive and active (volumetric) air samplings. For the passive samplings, three Petri dishes: blood agar (BA), standard agar (SA), and Sabouraud glucose agar (SGA) were left open for 15 minutes at each site and for the volumetric or active analysis, the Burkard Personal Volumetric Air Sampler from Burkard Manufacturing Co. Ltd. was used (see description in the Aerial fungal contamination of the NTCR). The Petri dishes from the passive air sampling were transported to the Medical Mycology Section laboratory at the School of Microbiology of the Universidad de Costa Rica, where they were incubated at \(37\,^{\circ }\)C (BA and SA) for 72 h and at \(25\,^{\circ }\)C (AGS) for three weeks. After incubation, the colonial morphotypes were analyzed and colony counts were performed. Seventeen sampling sites were selected for these experiments (Fig. 3B). The first nine were taken at the center of the room at three different elevation levels (ground level, 1.3 m and 2.6 m). These are the same locations described on Methods section Atmospheric measurements of the room. The other eight were taken at ground level, next to the positive sampling sites for fungal and bacterial isolation obtained from these surfaces (Supplementary Figure S2).Isolation of microorganisms from the murals and ceiling of the MOTwo sampling dates for isolation of microorganisms were conducted: June \(16^{th}\), 2023 (murals) and February \(9^{th}\), 2024 (ceiling). The samples were collected using dry sterile swabs that were rubbed over the sections of interest. Sampling sites were previously selected by an expert artist criterion: ten sampling sites from the murals and 24 from the ceiling painting. (Supplementary Figure S2). After the collection of samples, the swabs were immersed in 5 mL of 0.1 % Sterile Peptone Water and then transported at \(4\,^{\circ }\)C to the laboratory for further analysis. The swabs were used to inoculate BA, for bacterial isolation, and SGA with antibiotics (gentamicin and chloramphenicol) for fungi. The BA plates were incubated for 48 hours at \(35\,^{\circ }\)C. After incubation, bacterial colonies were microscopically analyzed with Gram staining, and later, they were identified using the \(\hbox {VITEK}^{\circledR }\) 2 System (bioMérieux, Marcy-L’Etoile, France). Each culture was deposited at a temperature of -80 ºC in a Brain Heart Infusion Broth supplemented with glycerol. On the other hand, at \(25\,^{\circ }\)C, the SGA plates were daily assessed for approximately three weeks. Subcultures of the different colonial morphotypes were performed on SGA and Potato Dextrose Agar. The purity and preliminary identification of the isolates were determined with lactophenol blue and clear lactophenol for hyaline and black fungi, respectively. Yeasts were identified using the \(\hbox {VITEK}^{\circledR }\) 2 System while filamentous fungi employing the \(\hbox {VITEK}^{\circledR }\)MS (bioMérieux, Marcy-L’Etoile, France).Atmospheric measurements of the roomAlso , due to our findings from the aerial fungal concentration data, we decided to measure the environmental properties of the room and outside, measuring: temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, and concentration of particulate matter.Using an Arduino-based air sensor developed by the Climatic Systems Observation Laboratory (LOSiC) for applied meteorology of the Universidad de Costa Rica, measurements were taken of temperature, wind speed, relative humidity, and concentration of particles (PM 1, PM 2.5, and PM 10) every 5 s in a 5 to 15 minutes periods in the center of the room and by the windows. The room dimensions were taken by a Laser Distance Measure Bosch GLM 50-27 C.The first set of nine measurements points were made in the center of the room at three elevation levels (ground level, at 1.3 m and 2.6 m, following the same distribution as presented in Fig. 3D) and three columns going from north to south with all the windows closed. The second set of nine measurements were taken once in the center of the room, by the south window, and by the east window closest to the door (see Fig. 4A and Supplementary Figure S3) with three scenarios of one window open, both windows open and closed windows. Outside each window, measurements were also taken.Because the atmospheric station had three wind speed sensors arranged in a triangular configuration, the x-axis and y-axis wind speed measurements were calculated using the following equations:$$\begin{aligned} & V_{x} = V_{1}-\frac{(V_{2}+V_{3})}{2}, \end{aligned}$$
                    (1)
                $$\begin{aligned} & V_{y} = \frac{\sqrt{3}(V_{2}-V_{3})}{2}, \end{aligned}$$
                    (2)
                $$\begin{aligned} & V = \sqrt{V_{x}^{2}+V_{y}^{2}}, \end{aligned}$$
                    (3)
                where \(V_{1}\), \(V_{2}\), and \(V_{3}\) indicate the speed measured by the sensors [m/s]; \(V_{x}\), \(V_{y}\), V correspond to the wind speed in the x, y axis [m/s], and its magnitude, respectively.The analysis for the mass flow of the particles was made with a fixed box model, which is used for air pollution analysis in cities described by De Nevers41. These models establish a mass balance in the control volume of the air in the city to be zero (i.e. \(m_{entrance}-m_{exit}=0\)). In accordance, in this model, the entrance flow is the particle flow entering through the south (or west) windows and the particles created in the room, which are assumed to be zero. The exit flow consists of particles exiting through the opposite west (or south) windows and the particles accumulated on the paintings and the mural of the east wall.The mass flow, \(\dot{m}\), is therefore calculated using the wind speed magnitude (see Equation 3), concentration of particles in the air and the cross-sectional area of the window when they enter the room, following this relationship:$$\begin{aligned} \dot{m} = c\cdot V\cdot A_{t}, \end{aligned}$$
                    (4)
                here c denotes the air pollution concentration [\(\hbox {kg/m}^{3}\)] and \(A_{t}\) is related to the cross-sectional area of the entrance [\(\hbox {m}^{2}\)]. As a consequence, the entering particles can be considered suspended particles as the terminal sedimentation velocity is several orders of magnitude less than the local wind speed. The sedimentation terminal speed, \(V_{s}\), can be calculated with the Stokes law, as the particle’s size D are between 1 \({\upmu }\)m to 10 \({\upmu }\)m, given by:$$\begin{aligned} V_{s} = gD^{2}(\frac{\rho _{p}-\rho _{air}}{18\mu }), \end{aligned}$$
                    (5)
                where g corresponds to the gravity (9.81 \(\hbox {m/s}^{2}\)), \(\rho _{p}\) indicates the particle’s density = 2000 \(\hbox {kg/m}^{3}\), assuming that the air particles are similar in size to carbon, \(\rho _{air}\) is the air’s density = 1.2 \(\hbox {kg/m}^{3}\), and \(\mu\) correspond to the air’s dynamic viscosity = \(1.8x10^{-5}\) Pa\(\cdot\)s.Simulation of flow and accumulation’s probability of particlesUsing the measurements of the chamber, a 3D model was made in the platform for modelling Fusion \(360^{\circledR }\) for the control volume. This was imported to the software ANSYS 2023 R2 where an air flow simulation of the room was done. For the model, we considered a scenario where the south and west windows are open. According to the cleaning personnel, this is the most frequently used scenario. The mesh size is 0.1 m, using over 900 thousand elements, while there is a maximum of 1 million elements in this case. The east wall and the ceiling were considered as a particle trap to determine the number of particles trapped from the surrounding pollution.The model used for the analysis is a dense discrete particle model (DDPM) to incorporate the wind flow and the particle flow entering the room. The particles flow and the wind flow are inserted in the normal direction to the entrance of the windows at an average temperature of \(25\,^{\circ }\)C, a dispersion parameter of 4, a rosin-rammler distribution for the minimum diameter of 1 \(\mu\)m, an average diameter of 4.8 \(\mu\)m obtained from the room measurements and a maximum diameter of 10 \(\mu\)m. The mass flow is dependent on the velocity so for each case the mass flow is calculated keeping the cross-sectional area and the particle concentration constant. The simulation configuration will be with a stationary phase model, the standard K-\(\epsilon\) viscosity model, gravity, and the energy equation are included. The initialization will be with a hybrid model and the solution for 300 iterations.In the control volume, four scenarios will be simulated: the flow entrance is the south window, and when the flow entrance is the west window and for an average flow velocity and a maximum flow velocity.Selection of deteriorations: definition and characterizationThe definition and the characterization of the deteriorations found is presented in the Supplementary Table 2.Degradation of coluor analysisFor the study of the luminosity and spectral characteristics of the painting by Paolo Serra, the colorimeter with UCR plate 399759, brand KONICA MINOLTA and model CR20 was used. In this measuring instrument, colors are represented using coordinates in a uniform color space consisting of variable luminosity \(L^{*}\) and chromaticity indices \(a^{*}\) and \(b^{*}\). For this case, \(L^{*}\) indicates the scale from black to white, a negative value of \(a^{*}\) corresponds to color green, a positive value of \(a^{*}\) corresponds to color red, a negative value of the parameter \(b^{*}\) corresponds to blue and a positive value of \(b^{*}\) indicates closer to color yellow. The measurement of \(L^{*}\) (around 4-6 experimental points per zone) was carried out in all the regions previously established as areas of interest due to the high probability that particles would settle there, based on the simulation carried out with the ANSYS computer tool. As a consequence, it would be expected that, in the northern region of this painting, the variation of the \(L^{*}\) parameter would decrease since a lower value of \(L^{*}\) means a darker luminosity. Thus, \(L^{*}\) has been plotted as a function of the position on the grid of the painting (regions close to the frame), where the number 1 corresponds to the region closest to the windows, i.e. the western region of the NTCR, and 6 corresponds to the region closest to the west wall. The west and east walls have been divided into regions approximately similar in dimension to the north and south walls.Since color change can be a subjective variable54, and depends on the observer, data from colorimeter measurements were used to estimate possible color variations using the \(L^{*},a^{*},b^{*}\) diagram mentioned above. To do this, the difference in each of the coordinates \(L^{*}\), \(a^{*}\), and \(b^{*}\) is calculated, and the Euclidean difference between two measured points is calculated, as shown in Fig. 5A. The difference is estimated as follows:$$\begin{aligned} \Delta E=\sqrt{(\Delta L^{*})^{2}+(\Delta a^{*})^{2}+(\Delta b^{*})^{2}}, \end{aligned}$$
                    (6)
                here, \(\Delta L^{*}\) denotes the luminosity difference between the two extreme \(L^{*}\) cases (for example for the northern region, see Fig. 5A, grid 1 and grid 6); \(\Delta a^{*}\) denotes the chromaticity index difference between the two extreme \(a^{*}\) cases (for example for the northern region, see Fig. 5A, grid 1 and grid 6), and \(\Delta b^{*}\) denotes the chromaticity index difference between the two extreme \(b^{*}\) cases (for example for the northern region, see Fig. 5A, grid 1 and grid 6). Criteria 55,56 for establishing the colour difference between the six zones in the ceiling painting were carried out according to Table 6. The results obtained from the painting of \(\Delta E\) were represented as \(\Delta E_{exp}\) in order to compare it directly to standard reference values. To evaluate \(L^{*}\), \(a^{*}\), and \(b^{*}\), a global ANOVA F test was used for each variable. From the data, we obtained that the standard deviation for each case corresponds to 0.998, 0.562 and 0.935, respectively. Thus, a combined standard deviation for the whole group reveals a standard deviation of 0.638.Table 6 Optical assessment of the colour distances \(\Delta E\), see Equation 6, as Euclidean distances in the chromaticity diagram which corresponds to a sphere visualization of colour. “N”, “E”, “S”, and “W” corresponds to the northern, eastern, southern and western sides of the painting, respectively. The east and the west walls were divided into two regions.Full size tableOptical and UV microscopyWith the aim of studying the cross-section sample of Paolo Serra’s painting, the samples were collected under the supervision of the Manager of the NTCR Conservation Department, using a scalpel from damaged regions to minimize the risk of further damage. The samples were set up by embedding in epoxy resin (Fibrocentro®) and polishing them with water sanding sheets (3M®) of 9.2 \(\mu\)m, 6.5 \(\mu\)m, 3 \(\mu\)m and 1 \(\mu\)m grit sizes for approximately 3 min with each sheet, in descending order. For fine finishing, a EcoMet 30 Buehler®polisher was used, for two 15-min cycles with 15 \(\mu\)m and 3 \(\mu\)m alumina abrasive (Allied High-Tech Products®), under the following conditions: 150 rpm for stage and 150 rpm and 30 N force for the support arm, which rotated opposite to the stage. A DX.2053-PLPOLRi Delphi-X Observer microscope was used, as well as an equipped DC.18000-Pro Euromex digital camera along with a DT 1000 CE UV/VIS AIS light source was employed with a SR fiber type with a 600 \(\mu\)m core diameter (please see Fig. 6A). To obtain the complete view of the sample, a composition of 108 photos using Adobe Photoshop® was made, since the 20x magnitication allowed an aproppriate view of the sample but took small regions only; therefore, a composition of layers and a panorama had to be made (please see Fig. 6A.2). To avoid scale problems through this manipulation of the photos, the correct scale bar was included at the end, considering the longitude of the sample from two points and getting the reference from the SEM analysis, using the software ImageJ 1.54g. The latter to determine the pigment crystal distribution as shown in Table 5.Scanning electron microscope – energy dispersive X-Ray spectroscopy (SEM–EDX)The samples were analyzed to determine their microstructure and elemental composition. Initially, they were examined using a stereoscope for macro photography. For microanalysis, each sample was mounted on a metal base and secured with double-sided carbon tape. Subsequently, the fragments were analyzed in a JEOL JSM-IT 500 scanning electron microscope under variable pressure, utilizing backscattered electron imaging to assess their structural characteristics. The SEM is equipped with a corresponding EDX detector, which facilitates elemental analysis of different areas of the sample, as well as specific crystals within cross sections.

              All data needed to evaluate the conclusions in the manuscript are present in the manuscript or the Supplementary Information and are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.
